150959525.review:
[h1] A Delightful Journey of Color and Creativity! [/h1] 

I recently stumbled upon this beautiful game, and I can't help but share my joy about it. "Townscaper" is a simple yet incredibly captivating game that allows you to unleash your creativity and build charming, colorful towns.

The game's concept is refreshingly uncomplicated - no goals, no pressure, just the pure pleasure of building. It's like a canvas for your imagination, where you can design quaint island towns, curvy streets, soaring cathedrals, and even sky cities on stilts. The possibilities are as vast as your creativity.

What truly sets "Townscaper" apart is its beautiful simplicity. The colorful palette and the easy-to-use block placement make it a joy to create your dream town, block by block. The underlying algorithm works like magic, turning your blocks into adorable houses, arches, stairways, bridges, and lush backyards. It's a mesmerizing process that never fails to bring a smile to my face.

The game's description perfectly captures its essence - it's more of a toy than a game, allowing you to immerse yourself in a world of beauty without the pressure of specific goals. It's a delightful experience that lets you unwind and tap into your artistic side.

One of the most surprising aspects is that "Townscaper" is incredibly affordable. For the sheer joy it brings and the creative outlet it provides, the price is a steal. It's a testament to the developers' commitment to making this experience accessible to everyone.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game that offers a unique and relaxing creative experience, "Townscaper" is an absolute must-try. It's a visual treat, a canvas for your imagination, and a delightful journey into the world of color and creativity. I can't recommend it enough!

149722536.review:
Townscaper is a fantastic and beautiful game, with relaxing gameplay and good looking, comic-style graphics, which can be perfectly used to let your creativity run free and relax while letting time pass.
After initially buying it, I just wanted to try it out and without me knowing half an hour was already over...
And after not playing it for over a year I just got back to it and it still got me for over 20 Minutes, after which I decided to write this review. Even though I don't have like 500h of playtime, it is still a great game to kill a few minutes and calm down.
I definitely recommend it to people who want to do something senseless whilst creating something beautiful.
Regarding the price: 5,99 € is more than fair and gets you this great chill experience!
Performance wise it should run just fine on literally everything, including the SteamDeck.

But I have some suggestions for improvement & feature requests (not only from me, I took some inspiration from other reviews):
[list]
    [*] It would be nice, to have more building types, like Bridges or Shops
    [*] Also a cool feature would be the possibility - in addition to the automated decision - to be able to choose which type of building topping is used, like roof structures, rooftop terraces, lighthouses, towers, etc..
    [*] Humans walking around would also add a nice touch to the game, because this way the towns / structures would be more alive (besides the birds).
    [*] Also multiple brush tools would be a nice addition, for example to arrange houses in shapes, recolour houses, etc.
    [*] For nice screenshots, alternative backgrounds would also be very cool.
    [*] For more building customisation different roof types would make room for new possibilities.
    [*] As an alternative to the normal camera view, I saw the idea for a 1st person view of one of the humans walking around your town, which you also can control, to go around the build town.
[/list] 

All in all it is a wonderful game to just chill out...
Definitely recommended!

[b]Tl;dr:[/b] Townscaper is a delightful, artistic gem for city-building enthusiasts and creative minds.

Townscaper is not your typical city-building game, and that's precisely what makes it so captivating. I am not a city-building game enthusiast, but as someone who likes to test out various gaming genres, I can confidently say that [b]Townscaper is a unique and immersive experience[/b] that left a lasting impression on me.

The first thing about Townscaper you should know is that it is a huge sandbox game that doesn't lead you toward a certain goal with its mechanics and systems. You have a huge box of sand you can play with, and you should figure out how to best utilize the tools you're given to create something creative. [b]In Townscaper, the player is the one who makes the game meaningful by setting a personal goal.[/b]

Before getting to play Townscaper, you should know that [b]it is a toy rather than a game,[/b] and you need to use your own imagination to make it as fun as it can be. [b]If this suits your expectations from a city-building game, give it a go![/b]

What is Townscaper? 

Well, Townscaper is more of a creative tool than a game, I would say. This app lets you build gorgeous and serene town, Mediterranean style(French? Italian? Something like that). I like it, but at the moment it's very barebone, just a bunch of blocks that you can slap together to create quirky architecture. If you like that, then go ahead. Unfortunately, it bored me out after the first 2 hours.
Additions I can recommend: people(I want to see humans living in their buildings), animals(the Mediterranean without cats and dogs running around, no seagulls flying overhead, no fishes leaping out of water in the distance: is not the Mediterranean at all), different kind of businesses(at least add a fish market and a dock, you know, the game is literally surrounded by water).
Otherwise, it's literally a tool. Maybe if you're an architecture looking for ideas, sure. I'm a general Joe, so i'm not much immersed in it.

144008248.review:
This is a great relaxation game if you really want to waste an hour or two. Though some things that would make the game better are as follows:
1. Different build materials, i.e. wood or metal
2. Shop Fronts (Maybe? Not Priority)
3. Market stalls and other things to go on the streets like wells
4. A Big one is people. The game is really colorful but after a time of playing it... It feels dead, like a ghost town. There's no activity or really anything going on.
5. Brush/ placement controls
6. A modding community. Even if only for resource packs, many people could add things nobody would've thought about, but that are great additions to the game.
7. Another big one is land. Even if just a small island, it would make the game so much more interesting. You could build a city hanging off the side of a cliff over the water, imagine how cool things like that would be. 
8. Weather! The game has only night and day, which you must manually control. It makes the game feel like it's in a really choppy simulation. Storms would be very cool, especially if there were lightning rods on the roofs. 
9. Animals!
10. The sounds of a city! Dogs barking, cats meowing, haggling in the streets, maybe a musician or two. and the hustle and bustle sounds that make a city feel alive.
That's all, hope this review was helpful!

143930054.review:
It's a charming "game" (more like a toy?), however it's lacking some needed features:
[list]
[*] First person mode or Free camera mode (currently there's only Perspective camera which always faces to a point in space);
[*] A functional .obj export (in the Steam version the obj export messes up the color of your buildings when exported, meanwhile the GOG version seems to be fixed, imo that discrepancy is unacceptable).
[*] Official mod support.
[*] Workshop support.
[/list]
I believe it's missing more things, but if we had at the very least mod support and a workshop, the community could band together and expand the game. That's just wishful thinking tho, as the game is called as complete by the developer. 

Don't get me wrong tho, it's impressive what they did with this toy, as in being able to spawn cutesy coastal cities with so little effort and all procedurally, demands an incredible amount of effort and craftsmanship which I respect. But calling this toy complete when one of the features is barely functional (obj export) is weird, more so when the GOG version reportedly doesn't have that problem.

All in all it's an experience that only you can tell if it's worth or not. So give it a go with the demo and if you like it, try the full version (which is not that different). This is just not for me for the aforemetioned reasons, anyway ty for reading.

143762544.review:
After 7 hours of playing sickly and obsessively, I can say that when I close my eyes I see the constructions I made. When I go to sleep, I dream of myself walking across the cities I built. And when I see buildings in the real life, I realized  most of them are made of imperfect cubic blocks, just like in Townscape.

Is like a combination of Cities Skylines, playing with your childhood blocks, and european cities like Bruges or Vernice in a subtle combination... but without problems. You can't lose the game, but you can't win either. I shared some of my cities in the not so much populated Townscaper sub-reddit .

Well. I haven't found the "Save City" option yet. Would be a good aggregate. I've had to destroy my creations to build new ones. Only the vanishing memory (and a couple of screenshots) remain of my first cities.

I recommend this game. You'll relax or become mad. Or either both.

143742168.review: Currently loving the game, the simplicity to me is absolutely amazing. You can create a nice small seaside village in just half an hour and the juxtaposition between the perfect vertical grid and imperfect horizontal grid makes your towns look so much better and so much more like a real life village. In this game you can not only just build towns and move on, you can create history about what has happened in your wonderful creation, social hierarchy, war, racism. so anyway 10/10 game absolutely recommend it

You cannot, however, control much of anything in the way of what is built; you may ONLY control the color. You click on a space (either one on water or one on a building you already built), and a construct is automatically constructed. Hence while there seems to be a small amount of variety in what the product looks like in the end, the "player" (if this were a game) has very little sense of agency. But I suppose this could be fun if you don't mind not "playing" a "game" and just want to paint some (albeit very similar looking) houses.

140664595.review:
Townscaper is cheap, relaxing and unusual in a good way. You have very limited control, yet can create something quite beautiful. 

However, the lack of control (for me at least) means quickly running into limitations. You can see from other player's screenshots that there are other features beyond the simplistic little 'cottage' houses however with idea how to create them and no control to guide the game to make them it's quite limited. I've found a few of those features, but with the limited control you're relying on the game to delight you with these little surprises, and very quickly it's become formulaic with a mix of frustration that I can't get it to create what I'm looking for, and boredom that nothing new is happening.

It's irritatingly static in the graphics too, whilst yes it responds dynamically to your changes, once you stop it all stops. I'd love to see people walk through the town, twee little fishing boats sail through the water, but no. As charming as the graphics are, it's beautiful, but it's held back from being a true masterpiece.

I'd like to say "it's only worth buying if you like this sort of thing" but it's too unique to draw a comparison to other games, so I'll say probably worth it if you don't mind throwing a fiver away for a couple of hours entertainment.

137161218.review:
I really like the concept of this game but I feel like it could use some quality of life changes, and it has a lot more potential that is currently under used. I also have some extra suggestions that I just think would be neat.

These suggestions are in order of what I think is most important.

MOST IMPORTANT

Drag to place:
You could quickly place tiles in the same layer by clicking and dragging, and it would place tiles following your cursor. You could hold shift and drag up and it would place blocks in the same column. Maybe you could hold tab or enter and you could quickly place a "square" (because of the irregular tile shapes it wouldn't be a perfect square) of tiles on one layer. Like holding left click and selecting multiple icons at once on your desk top. I'm not super sure how to describe it but I hope that gets my point across. Currently for me it feels better to use my touchscreen rather than my mouse to add tiles because it's faster and I feel like it's easier to not miss click.

Alternate grids:
I'd like to have a square grid or free placement to make more custom placements would be great. I'd like to make circular courtyards in specific areas and such.

Placing grassy areas:
It would be nice to be able to place grassy or foresty areas to make parks, and field plots to flesh out the town a bit.

Optional courtyard:
I'd like the choice between keeping the paved paths where courtyards are automatically generated. Like you could click a brush on the side and turn the courtyards green instead of it being automatic. It would also be nice to be able to use the courtyard tiles as the normal path tiles.

Ability to chose building style:
Theses a few styles of buildings for the different layers of the town, and it would be nice to have an optional advanced building UI that allows you to chose which building you want to place for each layer.

LESS IMPORTANT

Choosing path border colors:
It would be nice to be able to change the border on the path tiles from red to the other colors that are available for the houses.

More background options:
I like the ocean scene, but I think a grassy and/or foresty background would be nice.

More building styles:
More buildings and styles of buildings would be nice, but that would come out to be the very lowest thing on my list of suggestions vs the rest of the building tool updates because it would require making a lot of new models and textures, and I would prefer the extra build tools.

I do really like the ability to export the towns as .obj files, because they would be cool to 3D print. You could use them as model bases or TTRPG terrain. Other formats would be nice, because more options are always nice, but it's cool that you let us export it at all.

I'd personally like the suggestions I listed because I would like to use this game as a reference for my D&D campaign town maps because I feel like it would be a really good and easy to use tool with a few tweeks. I would say the drag to place and the alternate grids would be the most important to do something like what I want to do, since I could just take a screenshot and label the buildings with editing that are important, and it doesn't have to be a 1:1 for it to be a good reference map as long as I had more placement freedom and easier to use building tools.

I understand if you don't want to add all this since it's such a cheap game and it's very worth the $3.59 I bought it for on sale, but these are just things that I think would be really useful for me personally and other DMs that want an easy to use, cheap, and fun map maker.

Thank you for reading and thank you for the game!

136725366.review:
Townscaper is a mobile app that's been dumped on Steam as if it was a real PC game (it's not)... it's a cash grab from greedy mobile devs.  This mobile app isn't even a game, it's, well, like a playpen or a fidget spinner, I guess.  You click around on a small 3D rendered map and buildings pop up.  Depending on where and how you click, the buildings may take various different forms like a tower or something.  You can choose what colours the buildings will be from a palette on the side of the screen.  That's all there is to this.  Visual bubble wrap. 

For those unfamiliar with what actually makes something a game, a "game loop" describes the interaction and feedback a gamer has when playing a game.  Tetris, for example, has a game loop where a random block appears, the gamer interacts with the block to position it, and then the game decides if that finishes a row or not, increases the players score if any rows were completed, then gives the gamer another block to position.  Counter-Strike has a game loop where a player seeks another player, tests their skill against that player by shooting them or being shot, the computer rewards the player if they win, and then if the player survives, they repeat that loop.  There's no loop here, no true interactive feedback.  It simply is not a game, it cannot be "played".

It can be "played with", but then you can open up Excel and use your arrow keys to make the cursor move around in amusing directions if you really want... does that make Microsoft Excel a game?  No, it doesn't (except for the version of Excel that had that hidden flight sim easter egg... which is more of a game than this is!).   See what I mean?

There's not much else to say about this because it's not a game, which disqualifies this for recommendation to gamers as a game.  I suppose it's worth noting it looks nice... which just means it's a waste of effort that could have been spent more wisely on making an actual game.  This could have been the foundation for a charming Sim City style game or something... but no.  

There's also some technical defects that should be addressed if anyone still wants to go ahead and buy this non-game mobile app on Steam. 

From a technical perspective, as a mobile app, this doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

There's no options to change the resolution for the mobile app and not many meaningful ways to customise the graphics settings.  There's no way for gamers to ensure this mobile app is running at the native resolution of their displays... there's no guarantee this mobile app will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

Because this is a mobile app, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the iPhones that the mobile app was designed for.  These are unfortunate handicaps and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was an afterthought for the iPhone developers who are to blame for this.  The mobile app is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for mobile phones forces upon a game.  Once more, mobile devs have made gaming worse for everyone.  I didn't spend thousands on building a gaming rig just so I could pretend it's an iPhone.

These technical defects push this mobile app below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Townscaper has the preposterous price of around $6 USD ($1 more expensive than on the app stores, so that's a poke in the eye to PC gamers from these mobile devs), it's not worth it given the defects and shortcomings with the product, especially considering the sheer number of completely free, much higher quality games on Steam.

136269953.review:
If this looks like your thing than it will be your thing.

You only have one decision to make: place a block here or don't. Depending on where blocks are and aren't in relation to one another, the game will generate different looking buildings. You learn the game by playing it and that's what makes it fun. I just wish there was so much more to find. 

For the current price you couldn't ask for more but this really feels like a glorified proof of concept. A concept that, if fully explored, I could see myself paying ten times as much for. I wanna explore a whole world by building it and figure out it's rules and secrets. But as it is now it just leaves me wanting so much more.

+ Procedural generation is fun to figure out
+ Very pretty Studio Ghibli art style
+ Super cute and charming procedurally generated details 
+ Satisfying SFX

- You can only place one block at a time, which makes building larger structures a pain (mods help with that)
- Not enough greenery. The only way to get a green area is by enclosing said area with a wall, which is tedious and makes even medium sized gardens look cramped
- I wish there were more structures resulting from specific block patterns (like bridges, ports, bakeries etc.)
- Irregular grid pattern often keeps you from building symetrically

Townscrapper is an adorable little game that offers you to sit back and relax while watching your creations grow the more you build.

I, myself am not a very creative person, so I usually end up being a little bit frustrated, but not with this game. It is very relaxing to place your houses/towers and other tiles and think about what might look good.

You get to choose from a good variety of colors for your towers in case you want to mix it up or stay with one color only.

Townscrapper also comes with music that fits the Ambiente well, and the little aspects such as seagulls, little benches, bushes, and more make the experience truly magical, and I enjoyed every aspect of it.

A perfect game for everyone that wants to have a relaxing game and escape reality.

130716793.review:
Even as a "townbuilding toy" and not an actual "game", Townscaper is lackluster and leaves a lot to be desired. Despite what the devs might think, adding different colors to a single building type doesn't add nearly enough customization. Additionally, the tedious process of placing tiles one at a time, contrary to popular belief, is not relaxing but rather a chore. Even IF you spend two hours getting the tiles exactly how you want, the town is almost completely lifeless without any people walking or interacting. Lastly, your creativity is severely limited by the middle-of-the-ocean backdrop.

As it stands, Minecraft or even Roblox are better "town-building toys". Not worth $5.99, would only recommend if it was free or at most $1.99.

3/10

129665350.review: While Townscaper certainly has its charms, in my opinion it just can't hold a candle to the superior game that is Runescaper. With its intricate building system and vast open world, Runescaper offers a level of depth and immersion that Townscaper simply can't match. The varied and customizable characters in Runescaper allow for a much more personalized gameplay experience, whereas Townscaper's block-based interface can start to feel a bit repetitive. Additionally, the rich lore and storylines in Runescaper add an extra level of engagement that is lacking in Townscaper. Don't get me wrong, Townscaper can be a fun way to pass the time, but for a truly unparalleled gaming experience, I would highly recommend giving Runescaper a try instead.

124882379.review:
As you sit back on your chair, feeling relaxed after a hard day's work or school, you wonder which game should you play? One that uses the least amount of brain power but gives some enjoyment value...that game could be Townscaper!

Townscaper is literally a colourful indie game which allows you to build settlements on islands in the middle of the sea. It's like the old movie Waterworld but with more colours and no defence. You can have any shapes or sizes of your islands. Just be creative. Remember to relax and turn on some soft music!

Please don't expect a lot of functions because it is a simple game, developed by one person. I like this game because the graphics is nice and colourful, and it helps me relax in-between other games. No achievements, no stress. For the price during sale, I think it's worth trying it out, if you like simple-building games. Please help support the developer.

Note: This game is also available in AppStore and Google Play, which means it's a great game to entice your kids to create and build with colours.

Rating: 80%

123842403.review:
[h1]Plop[/h1]

It's the sound of progress.

Actually, it's just the sound the game makes when you add something.

You pick a color and click on a space. It adds a building. You don't get to pick what kind. Add a few more and maybe a park appears. Like the store page quote, the game has no goals, no gameplay, and apparently ... no life.

There are no people to live in the towns you make. There are no vehicles to wander the streets or go from port to port.
There is nothing to make you really want to build up your town other than to maybe say "look at the neat thing I made".

No offense but I was looking for something with a little more "action" to it. I like Sim City-like games but many of those have events or disasters, or just simply feel lived in compared to this. It looks nice but that's all it has, a nice visual.

If this review feels like it lacks depth, it does, but so does the game.

Townscaper is a city-builder in a different sense. Instead of managing and zoning, you click and a house pops down. This game is for designers, not managers. People who want true creative freedom over the buildings and structures they create.

Gameplay is endless. You can always approach the cities you create in a different way, which has resulted in a fun experience on both the first and one-hundredth play.

Graphics are nice but not flashy. The game is cute. It isn’t a graphical exposé, but it is still fresh on the eyes.

And best of all, it has been given to us for a nice price of 6 dollars with regular sales.

All in all, Townscaper was a nice breath of fresh air compared to the city builders that tell you to micromanage everything. I enjoyed my time in it, and I have a feeling you will too.

123704805.review:
Townscrapper is a great toy. The macro building effects like hooks, and gardens, and light houses, and flags are a lot of fun to build something fun. The micro details like windows, and support pipes, and benches, and tables, and looking glasses are superb. It's a fun toy to make a few little towns.

There are some opportunities, why is there not a fill bucket? If I make an outline I want to immediately fill the center. Why is there not a paint brush? Do I always have to destroy and rebuild? Click+Drag and delete would be great.

The real fun is making a game with the toy. My brother, co-op co-pilot in all games, and I made challenges. Make a university, a holy place, a wizard's tower, an obstacle course, "build something that represents resilience!" the winner was whoever made the best building.

This toy would absolutely up it's game if it became an actual game. Combining this with something like Totally Accurate Battle Simulator (TABS) where players could make an arena then have their pawns fight each other? Or incorporating elements of a tower defense game. Making sniper towers, or enemies behind corners? This toy could do so much. Defending a flying island from enemies? Yes please. Triggering a tsunami? or earthquake? or a fire?! 

Townscraper is a fantastic building block but only a building block thus far. It's a good toy and has so much potential to become a great game.

123685121.review:
[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
It's a semi randomised town builder with nothing going on.

[H1]The good[/H1]
The interface and visual style are appealing. The few sound effects that are there are good.

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
There is not much going on. It's just: “select a colour and click on the screen”. If there is water then a street spawns, otherwise a building. You can combine blocks and hope something nicer pops up. But it feels even less than bare bone. It is like 0.4 with more content needed but that is not coming. The videos overrate it (I wouldn't call it a game). It feels like a tech demo of some kind or perhaps a wall paper generator. 

[H1]Summary[/H1]
If you're looking for a game, I cannot recommend it. If you're looking for a tech demo or a wall paper generator then go ahead. I would not spend more than £1/$1/€1 on it. It’s sad as with more body this good be the foundation of a zen game

Very chilled, lovely to sit and design gorgeous towns.    Please do play this. At £3, it's a total steal.  

I've put about 50 hours and it's a real shame it's been abandoned.  OK, there's been floating towns added, but that was a glitch that the dev capitalised on. All the other ideas people have come up with have been ignored, and the dev's moved on.

After designing dozens of structures, the game loses its appeal, but you're still looking at dozens of hours of enjoyment before that happens.   I just wish people were walking around, or you could go for a stroll.  I wish there were shops, or larger parks got playparks in them.... I wish there were boats that would sail around.  I wish there were fish or dolphins... SOME life other than the birds.    

Ultimately, no matter what you create, it could be brutalist industrial with all the girders or a Tuscan-style mount with white houses, it will be devoid of life, which is a real shame.

I was so excited when this came out, and bought it almost on day 1.  The dev has said there's "more to come" a few times, but nothing substantial has ever appeared.

So, with a heavy heart I'm closing this chapter and uninstalling.   I hope beyond hope the dev returns to this and adds more stuff, because otherwise, there'll be games just like it that come out, and they'll have roads, shops, people, and poor, lovely Townscaper will get lost as a quaint game that inspired much better games that came later.

120691583.review:
This is a really simple and relaxing town building sim that is a great example of the phrase "limitations make creativity".
You can't place benches or light poles, or create roads. The only things you can place in Townscaper are houses, if enough houses are next to each-other they become stand-able ground, if you put multiple houses on top of each other they will become a tower.
That's the beautiful thing about Townscaper, you only place houses, the simulation makes them into a livable town. You have to work with the limitations of the software to create the town of your dreams. And I love it!

It's not perfect, obviously, the main issue being technical. After building to a certain point the simulation takes a really long time to process the landscape and add small details to it, you end up having to wait a few seconds, doing nothing, for the program to finish loading. But that just might be my pc.

All in all I think Townscaper is worth the price if you're looking for a relaxing time that can yield some interesting and beautiful towns.

120630860.review:
There is no game here. It's simply a virtual stress toy which is fine to some, but not me. Although the game is clearly all about creativity, there is no form of progression which essentially locks the player into a small box of choices, rather than expanding slowly and inspiring the player to think outside of said box.. Unlocking new building types and being able to choose what types of buildings are placed would make this game way more enjoyable, encourage different flavours of creativity and increase it's longevity tenfold without hindering it's focus on relaxation and avoidance of a set goal.

At 7 minutes I feel like I have seen everything that this "game" has to offer, that is probably a new record.
Notice though that I haven't said that it is bad though, because it isn't. It does what it set out to do quite well, the issue is that what it set out to do is incredibly lacking in content and ironically creativity,since it entirely relies on the player's. On top of that after my 7 minutes of playtime and watching the trailers I really don't see any increase in possibilities, nothing stood out as "that looks cool, I should build that", I've literally done everything.

The only downside I would say is that it bizarrely doesn't allow for player freedom, which inherently is an issue in a creative sandbox game with no goal. 
Want to have some stairs that go up to this other block? Nope, that's now a house.
Want a long tunnel under a bridge? Nope, that's now a long solid block.
Want to separate these to roads that are next to each other with a railing or gap? Nope, they are now attached and there's nothing you can do about it.

It desperately needs a feature that allows players to alter a block's type or shape. The game would keep it's simplicity and flow, but will allow players to build what they truly want to. I would argue that this is the primary reason that 7 minutes was enough playtime for me to think I'd seen everything, because the blocks always play out in the same manner.

It really gives off that feeling you would get while playing Minecraft where you're trying to build something but the blocks are just slightly too big for that thing you wanted to build, so now that thing needs to be twice as big as planned. And even Minecraft has started to fix that with the addition of different shaped blocks, fences, walls, windows and other decorative blocks.

Again it isn't necessarily bad, but for a game that does so little it has no excuse to be anything other than perfect, which it just isn't.
It's fine for players that just want to click and build blocks but there really isn't anything more to it than that. 

Personally I think I wouldn't have an issue with it if it was free as it comes off as a tech demo for something that might be bigger and better in the future, but right now it is a glorified fidget toy and not worth any amount of money.

120599283.review:
[h1]Short Review:[/h1]

– No puzzles or goals, just creative expression
– Simple to use
– Cute art style
– Little customization, but you can change it up a bit with mods or custom palettes
– Gives me inspiration for other creative projects
– Super chill and relaxing game!

[h1]Full Review:[/h1]

I’ve played for over 40 hours so far, and I can still see myself playing some more. This game is so chill, and I love it! A lovely little sandbox town building game. Cute art style. Colorful buildings. Fun little details that pop up sometimes (like clotheslines between buildings, or little sculptures in gardens). Simple to play. No puzzles or goals or objectives or obstacles, just creative expression.

I’m finding this game is also great for inspiration. Some of the towns I’ve created have happened sort of by accident or just evolved into something once I started messing around, but now they’re giving me ideas for stories or art. I’ve also seen people suggest using it to make maps for D&D campaigns, book worlds, etc. I’ve even seen fan art and animations, so clearly I’m not the only one feeling inspired!

I would personally like if there were a bit more customization. As it is right now, all you can choose is the color of buildings, where to put them on the grid, how to stack them, and the location of the sun for lighting. Certain build features can be manifested by learning little tips and tricks, but they still only work if you build in that exact way (e.g. you can get stairs, but only if you create a platform between two buildings with a certain setup). Roofs, archways, etc. form automatically based on certain rules (so you have some control, but you might have to adjust what you’re building to make it work). You can get a grassy area, but only if you enclose a section fully within buildings. I’d love if you could at least choose between pavement or grass for each separate area, and if you could add walls without whole buildings. Maybe some control over roof vs flat surface. But judging the game on exactly what it is meant to be—a super simple automatic builder—it succeeds. And there is still so much room for variety and creativity, even within the limitations.

Some good news though for people who want a bit more customization is that there are mods, created by other players! (Just search online to find them.) They don’t solve the problems I mentioned above, but so far I’ve seen ones that offer different texture/color palettes (you can also make your own pretty easily), the ability to change plant color, and weather. Just these few things can open up whole new possibilities (e.g. I used some darker color schemes to turn one of my builds into a vampire town).

So if you want something to just chill with, or an easy way to explore your creativity, this is cute, and I recommend it! If you’re looking for real gameplay or detailed customization, it might not be for you, since there’s not much more to it than plopping down buildings. But there can be a lot of creativity and planning involved, if you really get into. Even more so if you download or make your own palettes and textures. With the amount of time I’ve spent playing, clearly I’m enjoying it!

*Review (and pictures of my builds) can also be found on my blog (link in profile).*

[h1]Accessibility:[/h1]

(May not include everything)

– No accessibility options.
– Available for computers and some other devices, including touch screen.

"No real gameplay" is actually kind of overselling this software. There is no gameplay, period. This is not a game, not even a minimalist one, or a casual one. Certainly not a simulation one.

It's a simplified 3d modeller plugin, for slowly drawing building shapes. And it does even that poorly. A fixed selection of colours, a fixed set of shapes for a given set of grid elements, a fixed grid layout, no tool you can drag, no copy/paste or reuse, just one level of terrain or building per click.

It's cheap. But it still somehow feels too expensive for what it does and how poorly it does it.

An absolute gem of a game. Sandbox? Zen garden?

First enjoy effortlessly create aesthetic small villages.
Then enjoy the process of understanding, little by little, how the different interactions programmatically generate some elements (e.g. stairs, small flags, gardens) and awe in wonder when you accidentally discover something new.
Then start being ambitious and start building bigger, more complex cities. Colorful towns. Impossible, intricate, architectures.

119942162.review:
I can't recommend this simply because it's miscategorized. This has nothing that would make something a game. Just because something is 3D, that doesn't mean it's a game. A game should have objectives or a story or both. At least any kind of challenges, achievements, or metrics to show your progress as a player. Like, highest floor built, how many meters of pavement, or how many windows in total. This has none of it.

As a tool to build 3D townscapes, it's also kind of useless. Sure, you can make screenshots of what you have built, but the .OBJ file export is half-baked (it exports 3D object with broken textures). Texturing the 3D model to replicate all the shaders is not something a regular person could do with 3D Builder or Paint 3D apps, it should work out of the box or not be an option at all (like on mobile).

There is one cool thing about it though - you can share your creations really easily, you just copy the state of your build to the clipboard and send it to a friend and they can paste it back into their app. So, when Wordle became viral, I was able to build a tool that converted Wordle results into Townscaper buildings https://tarmo888.github.io/Wordle2Townscaper/

So, while I have tried Townscaper on desktop, laptop, Android mobile phone, Steam Deck, and even in the browser, it's just a cute tool for me, which gets boring after 5 minutes. It feels like a prototype, unfinished.

118457867.review:
[h1]General Information of The Review[/h1]

I do recommend playing this game and I feel like I got my money worth for how inexpensive this game is, however, I do wish there was even more to this game that would get updates in the future.

I haven't played a lot of this game, since I played it during troubles with my internet, but I do intend to come back to his game and chill out working on creativity practice. I still got a lot on what I want to do, even getting into modifications to the game as to make and have different textures for different looks/themes. For example, having a more winter season to the builds I make. This game is mainly just a tech demo proof of concept type work, which is pretty well implemented rather than explicitly saying "this is a tech demo" with only basic textures that has no character to it.

Also, I know this game is described as a toy. But I call it a game due to what I consider, and what a lot others consider, a game is. Some people had complained to me about my choice of words when describing this game, but they don't seem to understand I consider a game as anything digital displayed on a monitor display where the user is interacting with the medium. Legit, some of you need to calm down because I decide to use a word to describe this product.

[h1]Criticisms of The Game[/h1] 

Before I get into this section, I'm happy with the game and I want to see the best for what this game has to offer. This is why I have criticisms of this game, so that maybe updates can come out in the future for improving the game.

[b]What I'd Generally Like to See[/b]

What I would like to see out of this game is more updates to it. There is a lot of support for this game and I would love to see the base game get more features for it to be better fleshed out. Like I said before, this is basically a tech demo and it will still have a lot of work I personally view as unfinished for it to be considered as a fully finished game. 

[b]Price Not Equal to What You Get[/b]

The asking price of this game is $6, which I do think is a bit too high considering this is literally just a tech demo. I would say the better price should be $3 - $4 for what you are getting in this game. I know some may say "why would it matter if it is a couple dollars less, it's not all that expensive at $6 anyway", to which I say, you are wrong. I care about the value of the game, this being the quality and quantity of content in the game relative to the asking price. Despite the content being great quality, there truthfully isn't much for this game to ask $6 out of me. Which thankfully I got this on the Steam Summer sale for a cheaper price more close to what I would pay for this game.

If there were more features to this game, of the same great quality, I can see myself paying $6 - $10 if you added some more quality content. In fact, if you fully developed this game to be larger than it is now, I can see myself paying up to $15 for this game. However, the tech demo that it is now just doesn't seem worth the asking price of $6.

[b]Updates I'd Like to See[/b]

Let me start off saying this, if they want to live up to the $6 asking price, they should have better modification integration for this game. This game doesn't seem to get any updates, but this one is a must if you want to meet up to the asking price and then just do nothing after that. I really don't want to have to deal with 3rd parties modifying the game as to make this game have all or most of the features I'd like to have.

In no particular order, here is a list of updates I'd like to seer:
[list]
[*] Better modification support
[*] Playing music while building (I've only had menu music)
[*] Automatic day and night cycles
[*] Automatic and Custom seasonal changes (including snowfall for winter and leaves falling on the ground for autumn)
[*] Aquatic structures (Boats is a good example)
[*] More animal types (no humans, but could be toggle-able option)
[*] Better sharing of work, especially for cross-platform
[*] Better texture pack support
[*] Manual object manipulation after the automatic placements
[*] Two modes, one for relaxed back play and the other for more specific control
[/list]

[i]This is all of what I can think of right now, but there is for sure a lot that can be done to this game. At least have better modification integration, so we could have modders make these sort of updates to download ourselves. I know you can mod this game, which is why I said "better" with certain points in the list.[/i]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I think this game was worth the money I had paid for, especially since I got it on the Steam Summer Sale. It is a fun game and I see myself playing it for more hours to come. I like to use this game to use during some downtime and for when I want to relax at the end of the day. However, it isn't without criticisms and I would like to see the best for the future of this game.

116629315.review:
Is this a very simple game? Yes. Is this a fun and surprisingly addictive game? Also Yes.
I'm not exaggerating when I say it's a simple game, so don't expect too much when you spend the $7 for it. It consists of being in the water, with a small colour palette to choose from, and you place down blocks (can't choose blocks, it will auto change to either street/building/etc) to make a town, that is all. That being said, it is still a very relaxing and chill game to play. I like building games like this so this is very much up my alley. The art style is cute and I really enjoy the different animations that play out when the houses change depending on the structure. You can make a lot of different things with the small palette you have to work with, from small villages to giant mansions.
I've seen it said in reviews before and I also agree, that it'd be cool to have people roaming around the town as you're making it, would make it feel more alive, all we have right now are some birds on roof tops.
I think another thing that could add a lot of fun to the game would be different town starting locations, not just water, although it is fun to build ocean towns.
Overall, it's a cute fun little game, and if you have 7 bucks to spare I'd recommend giving it a go.

115378409.review: As Oskar (the developer) stated: this is a toy, not a game. It's a toy where you click click click to create a block, then a little tiny house, then a two story house, then a tower by clicking on the same spot. There are conditions when you click that will create a slightly different building, so if you create a 6x6 "wall" (of houses) and you destroy the middle block at the bottom, that will create a ark. Yes, that's it. How long this will last it's up to you, but I'm quite confident that even the most relaxed player enjoying to build a town one house at a time will soon get bored because, once you've find out about the different behaviour you get by using different colours, or the "flying" cities, or about gardens, the discovery is pretty much over. While this game/toy explicitly has no real purpose other than be visually pleasant, It lacks of some advanced techniques to make it last longer: you cannot chose anything else than the colour. They could at least add the ability to chose the type of the building, perhaps from just 3 options to keep its simplicity, like house, church or palace. Or maybe chose a prebuilt building. Or textures. Or at least to fill a f** circle with blocks without having to create one by one. I mean, something to give just a bit more control. It even has no music. Since the developer clearly stated that the development is basically over, this game is pretty much dead and there will be no further addition, it will likely be just this very limited clickclickclick forever. Someone has started to add mods (multiplayer and "first person" walk) but that requires to install a loader and a bunch of other files so that's not available, for example, on mobile. But it shows it would be simple for the devs to include that and much more. Some more effort from the developer, which is apparently surprised his game (toy) is selling so well, would be really appreciated, and it would definitely change this review to a thumbs-up because the game on its own deserves it, but in this moment it seems to me just a dead project

115373767.review:
More of a "toy" than a game, Townscaper is an objective-less take on the town builder genre where you work to make a village that's interesting to view more than functional. It's whatever you want it to be, within the limits of its systems. This is probably for a certain type of person, but if you're looking to tune the world out and *pop* a small world into existence, you could do worse.

It would be fun to see this concept expanded further, but that may be better as a sequel than to alter what's here. More architectural styles and more control over the map grid would be nice, however. And, as has been said, more people, animals, and vehicles.

Do not play this game if you have other plans for the day. I have been here less than an hour, and I am in love.

Build some houses. Then switch colors, and build more. Then go delete some of what you just built, because once you do, you will see darling little scenes come to life. 

Build a 3-wide, 2 story house over the water. Delete part of the first floor. A crane hook might appear. Build two houses a block apart. Now someone has hung a cute little clothes line. Build a house. This house has a roof. Now build another house that is 1 block adjacent, and two blocks higher than the first. That roof is now a balcony.

This game is incredible. The attention to detail is so exciting. You will smile every time you find a new little way of creating.
Do yourself a favor and go build some houses.

114787260.review:
The first thing that will appear to our eyes after turning on the Townscaper is simply the blue of the water. The map of the game shows the sea divided into a network of uneven, tiny sectors. Most of them are similar to a square, although there are also some similar to a triangle, a pentagon or even a hexagon. The grid of these sectors is not evenly distributed and from the ruler, on the contrary - everything here is curved, rounded, asymmetrical. At first glance, it looks strange, but when we start building our city, we will be captivated by the beauty of naturally twisted streets or houses with sometimes bizarre, irregular shapes.
Townscaper

But let's not get ahead of the facts. I wrote that we feel the magic of Townscaper from the first click and there was not a word of exaggeration in it. We click and here, with the strangely satisfying sound of a bursting bubble, foundations emerge from the sea. Click a second time and a house stands on the foundations. We click a few more times, floors are added and the house turns into a tower. We can also remove blocks that have already been placed - demolishing the foundations will make our house stand on steel beams. Such clicking is simply pleasant in itself and evokes associations with snapping a bubble wrap - but this is just the beginning.
Can you live here?

The real fun begins when we discover that by using different colors of the blocks and skilfully manipulating the surroundings, we can conjure up countless types of buildings. Do we want to build tenement houses instead of houses? Nothing easier. Or maybe majestic castles with towers and courtyards? This can also be done. Lighthouses? Cranes over the canals? Churches? Gardens full of greenery? Or maybe huge sky platforms floating on propellers? Also present.

Everything is doable, it just takes your imagination and hours spent experimenting and discovering the block combinations that the game's creator came up with. There is no menu with a choice of building types. All we have is a cursor and a color palette that we will change before placing the next object. Seemingly it is not enough, but it must be added that for anyone who has a bit of creativity, the hours will pass imperceptibly here.
I only regret emptiness

One more thing is worth mentioning. Well, Townscaper is just lovely. With every click, our town is enriched with new details - seagulls will land on the roofs of high tenement houses, clothes lines or flags will appear between the houses, benches and flower pots will appear near the houses, butterflies will begin to fly in the gardens. This can be counted endlessly.
Townscaper

But here too, the Townscaper's biggest flaw is revealed. The cities conjured up by the game are so wonderful that you feel sorry for not being able to do anything more with them. Although I love classic city builders, I can wave my hand at the fact that this game allows us to build everything and without embarrassment that instead of placing obstacles in front of the player, it lets the player into the sandbox, where there are no restrictions. But what hurts me is that I cannot see how the built city lives, that I cannot see its inhabitants, that I cannot walk along its alleys or swim through the canals by myself.

Perhaps these frustrations are a little premature. Townscaper is now out of Early Access, but is receiving further fixes, giving hope that we still have some big surprises to come. And without that, I can confidently say that I do not remember when the last time simple clicking gave me so much joy and relaxation.

113367575.review:
When enjoyed as intended, Townscaper is an effortless stress-reliever and an easy buy at this price point. 

However, it could be so much more. Many players (including myself) see the immensely useful applications Townscaper has for map creation, worldbuilding, and even role-playing. Unfortunately, the game's intentionally minimal interface only allows you to build in the confines of a mid-20th century coastal town. What if there was an option for a grass base instead of water? Or medieval buildings? Or different types of blocks that created unique features like shop signs and display windows? What if the rooftops could be weathered and old? or covered with snow? The possibilities are infinite.

This game's community is bursting with ideas on how to improve and expand the game, and I dearly hope the developers don't let these ideas go unheeded, because this game is truly a gem.

112422287.review: Townscaper is a fun little contemplative game where you plop down little pieces of land and then parts of buildings. You can select the color of the building chunk you set down, but that's about it... there's a lot of random elements like towers flying bunting OR laundry between them, birds settling down, etc. The way you arrange your buildings also affects what the land under them is. Is there a little courtyard? a green patch? A manhole cover? There's no "point" to the game, it's just a bit of stress-free fun and creativity.
